title: Electronic civil disobedience
text:
Electronic civil disobedience (ECD; also known as cyber civil disobedience or cyber disobedience) can refer to any type of <a href="civil%20disobedience">civil disobedience</a> in which the participants use <a href="information%20technology">information technology</a> to carry out their actions. Electronic civil disobedience often involves <a href="computers">computers</a> and the <a href="Internet">Internet</a> and may also be known as <a href="hacktivism">hacktivism</a>. The term "electronic civil disobedience" was coined in the critical writings of <a href="Critical%20Art%20Ensemble">Critical Art Ensemble</a> (CAE), a collective of tactical media artists and practitioners, in their seminal 1996 text, "Electronic Civil Disobedience: And Other Unpopular Ideas". Electronic civil disobedience seeks to continue the practices of <a href="nonviolent">nonviolent</a>-yet-disruptive <a href="protest">protest</a> originally pioneered by American poet <a href="Henry%20David%20Thoreau">Henry David Thoreau</a>, who in 1848 published "<a href="Civil%20Disobedience%20%28Thoreau%29">Civil Disobedience</a>".
A common form of ECD is coordination <a href="distributed%20denial-of-service%20attack">DDoS</a> against a specific target, also known as a <a href="virtual%20sit-in">virtual sit-in</a>. Such virtual sit-ins may be announced on the internet by hacktivist groups like the <a href="Electronic%20Disturbance%20Theatre">Electronic Disturbance Theatre</a> and the borderlands Hacklab.
Computerized activism exists at the intersections of politico-social movements and <a href="computer-mediated%20communication">computer-mediated communication</a>. Stefan Wray writes about ECD:
"As hackers become politicized and as activists become computerized, we are going to see an increase in the number of cyber-activists who engage in what will become more widely known as Electronic Civil Disobedience. The same principals of traditional civil disobedience, like trespass and blockage, will still be applied, but more and more these acts will take place in electronic or digital form. The primary site for Electronic Civil Disobedience will be in cyberspace.
Jeff Shantz and Jordon Tomblin write that ECD or cyber disobedience merges activism with organization and movement building through online participatory engagement:Cyber disobedience emphasizes direct action, rather than protest, appeals to authority, or simply registering dissent, which directly impedes the capacities of economic and political elites to plan, pursue, or carry out activities that would harm non-elites or restrict the freedoms of people in non-elite communities. Cyber disobedience, unlike much of conventional activism or even civil disobedience, does not restrict actions on the basis of state or corporate acceptance or legitimacy or in terms of legality (which cyber disobedient view largely as biased, corrupt, mechanisms of elites rule). In many cases recently, people and groups involved in online activism or cyber disobedience are also involving themselves in real world actions and organizing. In other cases people and groups who have only been involved in real world efforts are now moving their activism and organizing online as well.
History.
The origins of computerized activism extend back in pre-Web history to the mid-1980s. Examples include PeaceNet (1986), a newsgroup service, which allowed political activists to communicate across international borders with relative ease and speed using Bulletin Board Systems and email lists. The term "electronic civil disobedience" was first coined by the Critical Art Ensemble in the context of nomadic conceptions of capital and resistance, an idea that can be traced back to <a href="Hakim%20Bey">Hakim Bey</a>’s (1991) "T. A. Z. The <a href="Temporary%20Autonomous%20Zone">Temporary Autonomous Zone</a>: Ontological Anarchy, Poetic Terrorism" and Gilles Deleuze’s and Felix Guattari’s (1987) "A Thousand Plateaus". ECF uses temporary - and nomadic -"autonomous zones" as the launch pads from where electronic civil disobedience is activated (for example, temporary websites that announce the ECD action).
Before 1998, ECD remained largely theoretical musings, or was badly articulated, such as the Zippies 1994 call for an "<a href="Intervasion%20of%20the%20UK">Internet Invasion</a>" which deployed the metaphor of war albeit within the logic of civil disobedience and <a href="information%20activism">information activism</a>. Some commentators pinpointing the 1997 <a href="Acteal%20Massacre">Acteal Massacre</a> in <a href="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, as a turning point towards the internet infrastructure being viewed not only as means for communication but also a site for direct action. In reaction to the <a href="Acteal%20Massacre">Acteal Massacre</a> a group called <a href="Electronic%20Disturbance%20Theatre">Electronic Disturbance Theatre</a> (not associated with Autonomedia) created a software called <a href="Electronic%20Disturbance%20Theater%23FloodNet">FloodNet</a>, which improved upon early experiments with virtual sit-ins. The Electronic Disruption Theatre exhibited its SWARM project21 at the Ars Electronic Festival on Information Warfare, where it launched a three-pronged FloodNet disturbance against web sites of the Mexican presidency, the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, and the Pentagon, in solidarity with the <a href="Zapatista%20Army%20of%20National%20Liberation">Zapatista Army of National Liberation</a>, against the Mexican government, against the U.S. military, and against a symbol of international capital. The <a href="Acteal%20Massacre">Acteal Massacre</a> also prompted another group, called the <a href="Anonymous%20Digital%20Coalition">Anonymous Digital Coalition</a>, to post messages calling for cyber attacks against five Mexico City based financial institution’s web sites, the plan being for thousands of people around the world to simultaneously load these web sites on to their Internet browsers. <a href="Electrohippies">Electrohippies</a> flooded the <a href="World%20Trade%20Organization">World Trade Organization</a> site during the <a href="World%20Trade%20Organization%20Ministerial%20Conference%20of%201999%20protest%20activity">World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 1999 protest activity</a>.
Hacktivism.
The term electronic civil disobedience and <a href="hacktivism">hacktivism</a> may be used synonymously, although some commentators maintain that the difference is that ECD actors don’t hide their names, while most hacktivists wish to remain anonymous. Some commentators maintain that ECD uses only legal means, as opposed to illegal actions used by hacktivists. It is also maintained that hacktivism is done by individuals rather than by specific groups. In reality the distinction between ECD and hacktivism is not clear.
<a href="Ricardo%20Dominguez%20%28professor%29">Ricardo Dominguez</a> of the Electronic Disturbance Theater has been incorrectly referred to by many as a founder of ECD and hacktivism. He is currently an Assistant Professor of Visual Arts at the University of California of San Diego and teaches classes on Electronic Civil Disobedience and Performance Art. His recent project the <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20100120025238/http%3A//bang.calit2.net/xborder/">Transborder Immigrant Tool</a> is a hacktivist gesture which has received wide media attention and criticism from anti-immigration groups.
Examples.
ECD is often open-source, non-structured, moves horizontally and non-linearly. For example, virtual sit-ins may be announced on the internet and participants may have no formal connection with each other, not knowing each other's identity. ECD actors can participate from home, from work, from the university, or from other points of access to the Net.
Electronic civil disobedience generally involves large numbers of people and may use legal and illegal techniques. For example, a single person reloading a website repeatedly is not illegal, but if enough people do it at the same time it can render the website inaccessible. Another type of electronic civil disobedience is the use of the Internet for publicized and deliberate violations of a <a href="law">law</a> that the protesters take issue with, such as <a href="copyright">copyright law</a>.
Blatant disregard of copyright law by millions of Internet users every day on <a href="file%20sharing">file sharing</a> networks might also be considered a form of constant ECD, as the people doing it have decided to simply ignore a law that they disagree with.
Blockchain technology has been leveraged by EDC groups to help make them more decentralized, anonymous, and secure.
Intervasion of the UK.
In order to draw attention to John Major's Criminal Justice Bill, a group of cyber-activists staged an event in which they "kidnapped" 60s counter-cultural hero <a href="Timothy%20Leary">Timothy Leary</a> at a book launch for Chaos & Cyberculture held on Guy Fawkes Day 1994, and then proceeded to "force him to DDoS government websites". Leary called the event an "<a href="Intervasion%20of%20the%20UK">Intervasion"</a>. The Intervasion was preceded by mass email-bombing and denial of service attacks against government servers with some success. Although ignored by the mainstream media, the event was reported on Free Radio Berkeley.
Grey Tuesday.
On February 24, 2004, large scale intentional <a href="copyright%20infringement">copyright infringement</a> occurred in an event called <a href="Grey%20Tuesday">Grey Tuesday</a>, "a day of coordinated civil disobedience". Activists intentionally violated <a href="EMI">EMI</a>'s copyright of "<a href="The%20Beatles%20%28album%29">The White Album</a>" by distributing <a href="MP3">MP3</a> files of "<a href="The%20Grey%20Album">The Grey Album</a>", a <a href="Mashup%20%28music%29">mashup</a> of "The White Album" with "<a href="The%20Black%20Album%20%28Jay-Z%20album%29">The Black Album</a>", in an attempt to draw public attention to copyright reform issues and <a href="anti-copyright">anti-copyright</a> ideals. Reportedly over 400 sites participated including 170 that hosted the album. <a href="Jonathan%20Zittrain">Jonathan Zittrain</a>, professor of <a href="cyber%20law">Internet law</a> at <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a>, comments that "As a matter of pure legal doctrine, the Grey Tuesday protest is breaking the law, end of story. But copyright law was written with a particular form of industry in mind. The flourishing of information technology gives amateurs and homerecording artists powerful tools to build and share interesting, transformative, and socially valuable art drawn from pieces of popular cultures. There's no place to plug such an important cultural sea change into the current legal regime."
Border Haunt.
On July 15, 2011, 667 people from 28 different countries participated in the online collective act of electronic civil disobedience called "Border Haunt" that targeted the policing of the U.S.-Mexico border. Participants collected entries from a database maintained by the <a href="Arizona%20Daily%20Star">Arizona Daily Star</a> that holds the names and descriptions of migrants that died trying to cross the border territory and then sent those entries into a database run by the company <a href="BlueServo">BlueServo</a> which is used to surveil and police the border. As a result, the border was conceptually and symbolically haunted for the duration of the one-day action as the border policing structure received over 1,000 reports of deceased migrants attempting to cross the border. The Border Haunt action was organized by <a href="Ian%20Alan%20Paul">Ian Alan Paul</a>, a California-based new media artist and was reported on by Al Jazeera English and the Bay Citizen.
E-Graffiti: Texts in Mourning and Action.
In response to the political assassination of <a href="Zapatista%20Army%20of%20National%20Liberation">Zapatista</a> teacher Jose Luis Solís López (alias Galeano), in <a href="Chiapas%2C%20Mexico">Chiapas, Mexico</a>, <a href="Ian%20Alan%20Paul">Ian Alan Paul</a> and <a href="Ricardo%20Dominguez%20%28professor%29">Ricardo Dominguez</a> developed a new form of Electronic Civil Disobedience that was used as part of a distributed online performance on May 24, 2014 as part of the week of action and day of remembrance in solidarity with the Zapatista communities.
When users logged on to the project website, their web browsers sent mass amounts of page requests to the server of the Mexican President <a href="Enrique%20Pe%C3%B1a%20Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a>, filling their error logs with lines of text drawn from <a href="Don%20Quixote">Don Quixote</a>, communiques from the Zapatista Communities, as well as from texts authored by the <a href="Critical%20Art%20Ensemble">Critical Art Ensemble</a>. As a kind of E-Graffiti and form of Electronic Civil Disobedience, floods of HTTP traffic were sent from around the world as the books and communiques were written onto the error logs of their servers several thousand times by different users.
Öppna skolplattformen.
In 2020 a Swedish citizen initiative to build an app for accessing the data from the City of Stockholm’s official school system began. The background is that the <a href="City%20of%20Stockholm">City of Stockholm</a> had developed an official school system in-house. The result was a very expensive system (more than $117 million). The mobile application for parents and employees to use left user frustrated and complaining about complexity and horrible usability. As a result of this some parents decided to build an open source version mobile alternative using the API of the school platform. On February 12, 2021 the app was released and all of its code was published under an open source license on GitHub. Following this the city began to work against the new alternative citizen made frontend and tried blocking it by obfuscating the official webbapplications API-calls, reporting key people in the citizen project to the police, calling them out in the press as unlawful, etc.
During most of 2021 the city counsel and staff upheld their opposition but saw their costs rising and that there was an overwhelming support of the new frontend. The politicians in charge finally chose to step in in the fall of 2021 and open up a collaboration with the parents building the frontend.
